    <item>
      <title>Labor hits back at negative gearing 'shrill scare campaign' by real estate industry</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/labor-hits-back-at-negative-gearing-shrill-scare-campaign-by-real-estate-industry</link>
      <description><p>Shadow treasurer Chris Bowen says realtors opposed to plan to limit negative gearing to new housing are vested interests with no evidence for their criticism</p><p>Labor has hit back at a campaign against negative gearing changes by a group of large real estate agencies, arguing they are vested interests who have not produced any evidence for their criticisms of its policy.</p><p>The Real Estate Institute of Australia and major realtors, including LJ Hooker, Raine and Horne, Laing and Simmons, McGrath, Ray White and Century 21, have said they are going to campaign against Labor’s proposed changes to negative gearing using their databases of hundreds of thousands of landlords and tenants.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/labor-hits-back-at-negative-gearing-shrill-scare-campaign-by-real-estate-industry">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Nauru refugee and premature baby in critical condition after emergency caesarean</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/nauru-refugee-and-premature-baby-in-critical-condition-after-emergency-caesarean</link>
      <description><p>Baby unable to breathe without aid when flown off the island with Somali mother en route to Australia, immigration department says </p><p>A 22-year-old Somali refugee and her newborn baby have been medically evacuated from Nauru after she underwent a caesarean section a month prematurely.</p><p>The immigration department confirmed the woman and her baby had been transferred to Australia where they were receiving “appropriate medical treatment”, but declined to comment further. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/nauru-refugee-and-premature-baby-in-critical-condition-after-emergency-caesarean">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Duncan Storrar went on Q&A – now his personal life is dragged through the mud</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/duncan-storrar-qanda-personal-life-dragged-through-mud</link>
      <description><p>Storrar found his past was considered fair game in the media after he articulated with disarming clarity how the budget looks from the lowest rungs</p><p>A week ago nobody had heard of Duncan Storrar. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/qa-star-duncan-storrar-may-need-tax-advice-after-crowdfunding-success">How he must wish that was still the case</a>.</p><p>Friday brought fresh humiliation for the 45-year-old father of two. <a href="http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/qa-star-duncan-storrar-exposed-as-thug-as-public-raise-60000/news-story/40fa76230ca09820313a9372de4b0aa9">Melbourne’s Herald Sun dredged up his criminal record</a>, including stints in prison for threats to kill and breaching court orders.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/duncan-storrar-qanda-personal-life-dragged-through-mud">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Killer took own life over fears for blind wallaby in his care, inquest hears</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/killer-took-own-life-because-he-feared-blind-wallaby-would-be-taken-inquest-hears</link>
      <description><p>Peter Fittock, who died in Darwin’s jail on 22 February 2014, was serving a life sentence for the 1998 murder of his pregnant former girlfriend Debbie Batzler</p><p>A Northern Territory killer who had been caring for a blind wallaby in prison took his life because he was worried the jail’s animal program was under threat, an inquest has heard.</p><p>Peter Fittock was 61 when he died at Darwin’s jail on 22 February 2014.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/killer-took-own-life-because-he-feared-blind-wallaby-would-be-taken-inquest-hears">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Gay former student says school discriminated against him over his outfit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/inappropriate-openly-gay-former-student-says-school-discriminated-against-his-suit</link>
      <description><p>Angus McCormack says Girton Grammar school in Bendigo asked him to leave a function because he did not conform to the ‘dress code’</p><p>Parents of students at a Bendigo high school have been urged to support a former pupil ejected from a school church service over his “inappropriate” outfit.</p><p>The student, Angus McCormack, says Girton Grammar discriminated against him at the private Christian school’s Foundation Day service last Friday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/inappropriate-openly-gay-former-student-says-school-discriminated-against-his-suit">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/13/hong-kong-glue-bricks-pavement-beijing-visit</link>

      <title>Facebook trends: Zuckerberg invites top conservatives to talk and denies bias</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk</link>
      <description><p>As Facebook battles a report accusing it of suppressing conservative news, CEO says he plans to ‘invite leading conservatives ... to share their point of view’</p><p>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has announced that he plans to invite “leading conservatives and people from across the political spectrum” to talk with him about accusations of political bias at the social media company.</p><p>Zuckerberg made the announcement Thursday evening in a <a href="https://www.facebook.com/zuck/posts/10102830259184701">Facebook post</a> that continued to deny the allegations of bias and the claim that the Facebook trending topics team suppresses conservative news. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The German economy grew by 0.7% in first quarter, beating expectations and outpacing growth of 0.3% in the previous quarter</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T07:45:10.652Z">8.45am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Oil is down on a stronger dollar and a warning from Russia that a global oversupply of crude could last into next year. </strong></p><p>The dollar has recovered by about 2.5% from its May lows against a basket of leading currencies. Oil is traded in dollars so the stronger the currency, the more expensive fuel imports are for countries using other currencies.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T07:26:42.019Z">8.26am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Will there be any horror stories for markets on Friday 13th?</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/13/german-growth-more-than-doubles-business-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/13/the-arts-industry-has-the-right-to-be-angry-about-funding-cuts-it-cant-possibly-work-any-harder</link>
      <description><p>Defiance may seem heroic but running full programs with insufficient funding is a risky business. And the burden will fall on the workers</p><p>They’ve been calling the past week <a href="https://dailyreview.com.au/worst-week-ever-australian-arts/42216/">the worst ever</a> for the Australian arts. They’re not wrong.</p><p>The sector’s fears that Catalyst – the newly introduced arts funding program dispensed directly by the government’s arts ministry – would become an exercise of political favour and pork barrelling, seem to have come true. Almost half of the program’s four-year budget has been announced in its first six months, with an extraordinary $13m in grants rushed out as the government went into caretaker mode last weekend.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/13/the-arts-industry-has-the-right-to-be-angry-about-funding-cuts-it-cant-possibly-work-any-harder">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/13/tantalisingly-close-is-solar-thermal-energy-ready-to-replace-coal-fired-power</link>
      <description><p>Australian projects are viable already – now the industry needs investors willing to take a risk on large-scale renewable energy </p><p>Companies working on large-scale solar thermal projects in Australia say they are tantalisingly close to achieving the dream of building plants big enough to replace coal-fired energy in Australia.</p><p>Experts speaking at the Australian Solar Energy Exhibition and Conference in Melbourne last week said the technology had been proven in other countries, and projects in Australia were viable, but the challenge was getting major investors to gamble on something new.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/13/tantalisingly-close-is-solar-thermal-energy-ready-to-replace-coal-fired-power">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why are we surprised by every populist politician? Voting for them can be a rational choice | Jason Wilson</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/why-are-we-surprised-by-every-populist-politician-voting-for-them-can-be-a-rational-choice</link>
      <description><p>Commentators perplexed at the inconsistencies of Donald Trump are missing the point. Populist leaders are defined more by their style than their ideology</p><p>For at least the last 20 years, democracies around the world have been regularly subject to a mounting series of populist insurgencies. From France to Venezuela, sharp-elbowed political actors from both the left and the right have railed against elites, flouted the table manners of liberal politics, and are increasingly meeting with electoral success. </p><p>But it seems that every time this happens, it takes commentators by surprise. Witness the worldwide reaction to the rise of Donald Trump. First came denial, with <a href="http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/dear-media-stop-freaking-out-about-donald-trumps-polls/">even empirical journalists resisting what polling is telling them</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/why-are-we-surprised-by-every-populist-politician-voting-for-them-can-be-a-rational-choice">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Wolf Creek TV series review – Mick Taylor meets his match in outback slasher spin-off</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/13/wolf-creek-tv-series-review-mick-taylor-outback-slasher</link>
      <description><p>The murderous rampage continues in Stan’s new six-part small screen series which introduces a vengeful American college student and looks like a million blood-stained bucks</p><p>Could Mick Taylor, the psychotic flannel-clad killer played by John Jarratt in the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/australia-culture-blog/2014/feb/18/wolf-creek-classic-australian-films">Wolf Creek movies</a>, be a relative of Mick (aka Crocodile) Dundee? Perhaps an estranged long-lost cousin, psychotically furious about his doofus “you call that a knife?” family member’s surprise success? </p><p>Their stories may take place in diametrically opposed genres, and thus very different universes, but in a sense the two Micks are cut from the same cloth: both atavistic Akubra-wearing Australian bastards who send up stereotypical perceptions of the true blue alpha male. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/13/wolf-creek-tv-series-review-mick-taylor-outback-slasher">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/australian-television">Australian television</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tv-and-radio">Television & radio</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australia-news">Australia news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/horror">Horror (TV)</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 01:54:55 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/13/wolf-creek-tv-series-review-mick-taylor-outback-slasher</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/f4070c20a921aa7baf95ff186e91293bcd0352d8/0_91_2700_1620/2700.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=7800e795f0f469bf9799163bf31e953d">

    <item>
      <title>Celebrities protest at 'crazy' redundancy of Age arts critic</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/-readers-complain-the-age-sacking-arts-writer-the-weekly-beast</link>
      <description><p>Geoffrey Rush and Helen Garner petition editor over sacking of Philippa Hawker. Plus News Corp’s finest just can’t leave Waleed Aly alone</p><p>The arts community <a draggable="true" href="https://www.change.org/p/mark-forbes-keep-film-and-arts-writer-philippa-hawker-at-the-age/c">has come out fighting in support of Melbourne critic Philippa Hawker</a>, who was one of 30 journalists to be made forcibly redundant by the Age this week.</p><p>A petition to the paper’s editor-in-chief, Mark Forbes, to retain Hawker, who has been writing about film and the arts since 1997, has been signed by hundreds of readers, including actor Geoffrey Rush, writers Helen Garner and Christos Tsiolkas, comedian Magda Szubanski and broadcaster Phillip Adams. “Philippa Hawker is one of the most astute and engaged of the critics working in Australia. Her dismissal is a stupid and short-sighted decision driven by panic not sense,” said Tsiolkas. Garner said: “This is a crazy waste of a fine talent and decades of experience.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/13/-readers-complain-the-age-sacking-arts-writer-the-weekly-beast">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Turnbull starts fresh at the Brisbane markets while Shorten goes back to school, and the Reserve Bank holds out for changes to negative gearing. <strong>Elle Hunt</strong> rounds up the day’s action <br>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/09/guardian-campaign-catchup">Sign up here to receive your Campaign catchup in your inbox every afternoon</a></p><p>Good afternoon, and welcome to the first day of the election campaign – just 54 to go.       <title>Chiller: Kyrgios 'doesn’t understand what it means to be an Olympian'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/chiller-kyrgios-doesnt-understand-what-it-means-to-be-an-olympian</link>
      <description><ul><li>Australian team boss sets her sights on Kyrgios after Tomic withdrawal</li><li>Kyrgios all but dares Rio Games selectors to leave him out of team</li></ul><p>Nick Kyrgios is now in Australian Olympic team boss Kitty Chiller’s sights after Bernard Tomic’s Rio withdrawal.&nbsp;Tomic and Kyrgios were both warned by Chiller last week in response to behavioural issues on and off the court.</p><p>Chiller refused to speculate on whether Tomic had beaten selectors to the punch by ruling himself out of the Rio Games but made her views on Kyrgios clear, saying his “ill-advised” response to being put on notice by the AOC showed he did not know what it meant to be an Australian Olympian.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/chiller-kyrgios-doesnt-understand-what-it-means-to-be-an-olympian">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/nrl-star-junior-paulo-disguises-himself-and-plays-in-third-grade-park-match</link>
      <description><ul><li>Brother-in-law suspended for one year after sending Eels forward on</li><li>Rugby union administrator labels incident ‘sheer stupidity’</li></ul><p>Junior Paulo’s brother-in-law has been suspended from rugby union for a year for sending the Parramatta forward on to the field in a third grade park match. Eels coach Brad Arthur said on Thursday the club had dealt with the incident “in-house” and confirmed Paulo will line up for the Eels on Friday night when they take on South Sydney.</p><p>But the man who sent him on the field during Oatley’s 17-10 rugby union win over Beecroft in Sydney wasn’t so lucky. Oatley third-grade coach Hendry Lees – Paulo’s brother-in-law – was suspended for a year. The Samoan international wore headgear to disguise himself and played under an alias, coming on in the closing stages of the match on 30 April.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/nrl-star-junior-paulo-disguises-himself-and-plays-in-third-grade-park-match">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Jason Day shoots record-equalling round at Players Championship</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett</link>
      <description>• Shane Lowry and Justin Rose two behind leader at Sawgrass<br />• Jordan Spieth level-par 72, Danny Willett signs for 70<p>The angst Jordan Spieth suffered by virtue of closing his opening round at the Players Championship with a seven, the one number that may bring him out in a cold sweat, surely intensified with a glance towards one of the his playing partners. Jason Day, who has succeeded Spieth as the world No1, endorsed his status once more with a course record-equalling 63. Day had birdie putts at all 18 holes.</p><p>As Day tapped in for birdie at the 9th, their 18th, Spieth was about to three putt for a double bogey. Spieth’s frustration at a 72 on a day of generally excellent scoring was compounded by that seven; the same scorecard aberration that fatally undermined his hopes of defending the Masters, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/11/danny-willett-masterrs-2016-jordan-spieth-lee-westood" title="">owing to a capitulation at Augusta National’s 12th hole</a>. Spieth later insisted his Thursday score did not appropriately represent his performance. “I really only had two bad swings today,” he said. “I’m hitting the ball great.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 20:59:33 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett</guid>

    <item>
      <title>Do AFL fans really still care about grudge matches like Dangerfield's return?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/do-afl-fans-really-still-care-about-grudge-matches-like-dangerfields-return</link>
      <description><p>As the Geelong man returns to Adelaide to face his old side, we might see whether grudge matches still resonate with AFL fans in 2016</p><p>In times such as these, guessing the precise motivations of AFL fans is a fool’s errand. But you do start asking yourself a few questions. For the price of his admission to Metricon stadium, should a grown man flanked by children really be entitled to lean across a fence and unload an ugly, vein-bulging stream of invective at such an affable, softly-spoken champion as Gary Ablett?</p><p>And in this era of equalisation, free agency and every-man-for-himself, get-the-money-while-you-can individualism, should even we fans who foot the bill really blame footballers for acting as we would in our own careers in seeking out the most lucrative and satisfying employment available? </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/do-afl-fans-really-still-care-about-grudge-matches-like-dangerfields-return">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>NRL Indigenous round a 'celebratory' moment of cultural pride | Paul Connolly</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/nrl-indigenous-round-a-celebratory-moment-of-cultural-pride</link>
      <description><p>Not only a showcase of sporting achievement and pride, the NRL’s Indigenous round provides Australia with a positive glimpse of Indigenous culture</p><p>Dean Widders could have let it slide. He could have dismissed it as a verbal haymaker in the heat of battle and moved on. But he didn’t. No, after South Sydney Rabbitoh, and former teammate, Bryan Fletcher, called him a “black cunt” during a 2005 NRL match, Parramatta’s Widders chose to speak out about it, to willingly throw himself into the middle of a media and cultural whirlpool. Why? “Because unlike many other Indigenous people,” says Widders – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/jan/22/how-rugby-league-player-dean-widders-stared-racism-in-the-face-and-won">who has spoken of his distress in that moment</a> – “I had a chance to have my voice heard, and I knew I could be a positive influence on my people.”</p><p>Widders, now the NRL’s Indigenous welfare and education manager, is a great believer in the power of positivity. It’s one reason he’s a strong supporter of the NRL’s continuing efforts to acknowledge Indigenous culture and the enormous contribution Indigenous athletes have made to rugby league. Initiatives like this weekend’s “Indigenous round”, and the pre-season Indigenous All-Stars v World All-Stars match, serve a dual purpose, he believes. One is that they help the NRL’s Indigenous players “strengthen their relationship with their own heritage” while also conveying a positive message about Indigenous culture to non-Indigenous Australians.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/13/nrl-indigenous-round-a-celebratory-moment-of-cultural-pride">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Successful women: it’s not only what they do, but what they don’t | Gaby Hinsliff</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/successful-women-pursuit-perfection</link>
      <description>As girls we are taught to do our best and to please others. But the pursuit of perfection has a dark side<p>Do less. Sleep more. Be gentle with yourself. Granted, it’s not exactly a thrusting mantra for success. No minor public school would choose it for a motto, and it’s hardly the stuff of a bestselling time-management book. What ambitious person wants to be told that actually there are only 24 hours in a day, and that sometimes the best way to squeeze more out of them is to stop trying so dementedly hard?</p><p>So it was easy to scoff at the sight of the recently reformed workaholic Arianna Huffington piously advising Hillary Clinton last week to <a href="http://uk.businessinsider.com/arianna-huffington-hillary-clinton-politics-democrat-presidential-2016-4?r=US&amp;IR=T" title="">stop “trying to do everything”</a> and make room for something called “self-care”. Seriously? Right now?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/successful-women-pursuit-perfection">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>We often know when drought or floods will strike. So let's act before they do | Neil Marsland</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/el-nino-farmers-frontline-drought-floods-building-resilience</link>
      <description><p>Climate change and the current strong El Niño are creating costly humanitarian crises. But it’s so much cheaper to avert disaster through building resilience</p><p>The life of a farmer in Somalia is never easy and, right now, it’s about as hard as it gets. The weather <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/nov/23/somaliland-climate-change-drought-cyclones-life-or-death-challenge">no longer seems to follow recognisable patterns</a> and the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/mar/16/drought-high-temperatures-el-nino-36m-people-africa-hunger">El Niño phenomenon</a> is exacerbating the crisis.</p><p>At 47 years old, Maymuno Madobe Cali has seen it all: drought, floods, disease and conflict. She knows only too well how a precious but fragile livelihood can vanish. She lost 26 goats the last time floods and water-borne diseases came to Boodaale and she is praying the same will not happen to her remaining 11 animals. With seven people in her family, another spell of bad weather could push her to the brink. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/13/el-nino-farmers-frontline-drought-floods-building-resilience">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Why Brexit would be the perfect gift for Vladimir Putin | Garry Kasparov</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/brexit-perfect-gift-vladimir-putin-eu</link>
      <description>An EU without Britain is exactly what the Russian president wants: a weakened institution with less power to confront his assaults on Europe’s borders<p>Politics often makes for strange bedfellows. Far-right parties in the UK and across Europe push for anything that will weaken the European Union – a goal shared by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/vladimir-putin" title="">Vladimir Putin</a> and Donald Trump. This week, their fellow Brexiteer Boris Johnson went as far as to repeat the Kremlin line that Europe is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/09/boris-johnson-cameron-cant-cut-immigration-and-stay-in-eu" title="">partly to blame for Putin’s ongoing invasion of Ukraine</a>.</p><p>One does not expect clear policy statements from Trump or Johnson, but Putin’s reasoning is irrefutable. His goal is to weaken the institutions, including Nato and the EU, that could thwart his neo-Soviet ambitions. The Kremlin was in mourning when Scotland narrowly voted to stay in the UK. Putin sees Europe as his enemy and wants his&nbsp;adversaries to be divided, smaller and weaker.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/brexit-perfect-gift-vladimir-putin-eu">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Don’t be fooled by the diplomatic words, because peace hasn’t broken out. The Republican power-brokers still loathe Trump, and Ryan is their standard bearer</p><p>When Donald Trump met with Paul Ryan in Washington on Thursday, you could say it was a meeting between the current and possibly future nominee of the Republican party.       <title>Why people vote Trump: the death of the American dream – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/video/2016/may/12/why-people-vote-donald-trump-indiana-death-american-dream-video</link>
      <description><p>Alongside Donald Trump’s nasty rhetoric, the Republicans’ presidential hopeful has been banging on about one huge issue: US firms increasingly moving jobs abroad, and the country’s rising sense of decline.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/malcolm-turnbulls-growth-plan-will-boost-national-income-by-just-06-grattan-institute</link>
      <description><p>Thinktank says economic effects of $48bn 10-year program of company tax cuts could be negative in short term</p><p>Malcolm Turnbull’s jobs and growth plan will boost national income by 0.6% at most and that benefit will take decades to happen, according to a leading economist.</p><p>A day after the Coalition accused Labor of “lying” about the economic benefits of its education spending, it stands accused of overstating the economic benefits of its $48bn 10-year program of company tax cuts – the centrepiece of Turnbull’s budget and its election campaign.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/malcolm-turnbulls-growth-plan-will-boost-national-income-by-just-06-grattan-institute">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/australian-budget-2016-hits-poor-families-hardest-modelling-shows</link>
      <description><p>Australian National University analysis shows lowest 20% of income earners lose 1.5% of disposable income and the highest 20% lose 0.2%</p><p>The 2016 budget hit poor families hardest even though high income earners were slugged through tighter superannuation tax concessions, according to new modelling.</p><p>The analysis by Australian National University associate professor Ben Phillips found the main changes in the budget left Australian households $345 a year worse off, on average.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/australian-budget-2016-hits-poor-families-hardest-modelling-shows">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/two-men-killed-by-train-in-melbourne</link>
      <description><p>Police say train driver tried to stop when he saw the men, who are believed to have been on the tracks at Altona Meadows</p><p>The train that hit and killed two men in Melbourne was moved on Friday morning and police were conducting a search along the tracks.</p><p>The men, who were yet to be identified, were believed to have been on the tracks at Altona Meadows in Melbourne’s south-west on Thursday night when they were struck by a city-bound passenger train at 11.45pm.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/13/two-men-killed-by-train-in-melbourne">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ken Wyatt's battle in Hasluck: can the first federal Indigenous frontbencher hold his seat?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/election-2016-can-ken-wyatt-hasluck-first-federal-indigenous-frontbencher-hold-his-seat</link>
      <description><p>On a 6% margin, Wyatt – the first Aboriginal member of the House of Representatives – faces boundary changes and a well-known GP and local historian on Labor’s ticket<br>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/live/2016/may/10/australian-election-2016-warning-over-aaa-rating-as-greens-back-labor-in-hung-parliament-politics-live">Follow the day’s developments live</a><br>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/09/guardian-campaign-catchup">Sign up here to receive the Campaign catchup in your inbox every afternoon</a></p><p>Ken Wyatt’s campaign team is discussing spare pants. “We should make sure that everyone has jeans and casual shoes in the office to go with the T-shirts, because a suit pant can look incongruous,” a staffer notes. It’s week one of an eight-week election campaign and, in Wyatt’s electorate office in Forrestfield shopping centre, 23km east of Perth, Western Australia, the details are still being mapped out.</p><p>It will be a fight. <a href="http://www.aec.gov.au/profiles/wa/hasluck.htm">Hasluck</a>, the outer metropolitan seat Wyatt has held since 2010, is being targeted by the Labor party as one of its potential gains in the west. Internal Liberal party polling of the neighbouring seat of <a href="http://www.aec.gov.au/profiles/wa/burt.htm">Burt</a>, <a href="https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/wa/a/31557895/liberal-poll-finds-new-seat-of-burt-is-50-50/">leaked to the West Australian newspaper this week</a>, showed a notional swing of 6% toward Labor. Wyatt currently holds Hasluck on a margin of 6%.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/12/election-2016-can-ken-wyatt-hasluck-first-federal-indigenous-frontbencher-hold-his-seat">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/great-barrier-reef-boat-fire-police-say-blaze-may-have-started-in-engine</link>
      <description><p>Three passengers in their 50s and 60s remain in hospital following the blaze on the 25-metre catamaran, which forced 46 passengers to abandon ship</p><p>A boat fire off the southern tip of the Great Barrier Reef that forced more than 40 tourists to escape into life rafts is believed to have started in the ship’s engine.</p><p>The now-sunken Spirit of 1770 <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/11/tourists-rescued-from-boat-that-caught-fire-off-great-barrier-reef-island">caught fire in waters 18km off the coastal community called Town of 1770 on Wednesday afternoon, close to Lady Musgrave island</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/great-barrier-reef-boat-fire-police-say-blaze-may-have-started-in-engine">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p> Group wandered into Iranian territorial waters in the Persian Gulf and were held for 15 hours before intervention by US secretary of state secured release</p><p>A US navy officer has been stripped of his command over the capture by Iran of 10 American sailors who <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/12/iran-detains-two-us-navy-ships-persian-gulf">wandered into its territorial waters</a>.</p><p>In a statement on Thursday the navy said it had lost confidence in Commander Eric Rasch, who was the executive officer of the squadron that included the 10 sailors at the time of the January incident.       <description><p>Administration will send decree saying all students must have access to facilities consistent with their gender identity, even if others object</p><p>The Obama administration will order all US public schools to allow transgender students to access restrooms that match their identities in a move that escalates the national fight over LGBT rights that has erupted in response to <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/09/lgbt-bathroom-bill-north-carolina-justice-department">North Carolina’s controversial “bathroom bill”</a>.</p><p>The US justice department and department of education will send the decree, a copy of which was obtained by the Guardian, on Friday.     <item>
      <title>When it comes to interracial romances, the movies need to catch up</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up</link>
      <description><p>Almost 50 years after Kirk and Uhura’s kiss on Star Trek, there are plenty of parts for black women - provided they want to play blue- or green-skinned aliens …</p><p>“Interspecies love is in the air!” enthuses <a href="http://teaser-trailer.com/warcraft-movie-anduin-lothar-and-garona-halforcen/">one movie fansite</a> at the prospect of the forthcoming Warcraft movie.</p><p>There’s a lot to get up to speed with in Warcraft. The original video games were so wildly popular that their community of players exceeds the population of Norway, and the <a href="http://wowwiki.wikia.com/wiki/Portal:Main">World of Warcraft wiki</a> has over 100,000 pages. For novices, it’s a fantasy world not far removed from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/lord-of-the-rings">Lord of the Rings</a> or Dungeons and Dragons: a realm of elves, dwarves, mythical creatures and medieval weaponry. Warcraft the movie revolves around Azeroth, a kingdom apparently ruled by European humans. Azeroth is invaded by orcs: hulking, relatively primitive ogres with overdeveloped lower canines. Rather than open arms, Azeroth greets these refugee orcs with medieval arms. “They’re beasts. They should all be destroyed,” says one character. It’s essentially a race war, although the battle lines are by no means cut and dried, so there’s still room for a bit of interspecies love.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Science hasn't 'proved' that women go for bad boys | Girl On The Net</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2016/may/12/science-hasnt-proved-that-women-go-for-bad-boys</link>
      <description><p>Some argue that the claim that ‘women love bad boys’ is scientifically proven. However, this isn’t the case</p><p>“Women always go for the bad boys.” “Nice guys finish last.” “Treat ‘em mean, keep ‘em keen.”</p><p>There are so many variations on the idea that women brush off advances from lovely men and instead deliberately chase guys who are tall, dark and horrible. If it’s true, why is the crime rate not significantly higher, as straight guys compete with each other to look “badder” than their friends? In fact what do we mean by “bad” anyway? Are we talking bank robbers, or just your mate Clive who once dumped a girl via text? </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2016/may/12/science-hasnt-proved-that-women-go-for-bad-boys">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/science">Science</category>

      <title>How to cook the perfect aloo gobi</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2016/may/12/how-to-cook-the-perfect-aloo-gobi</link>
      <description><p>This Punjabi potato and cauliflower curry is now a prized dish across India and Pakistan. But for the best texture, should the potatoes be waxy or floury? And which spices bring out its comforting warmth?</p><p>According to chef <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/23/vivek-singh-indian-dishes-with-stories-to-tell">Vivek Singh</a>, this hearty cauliflower and potato dish is probably “the most common and basic vegetable curry you will find anywhere in India”. Cheap, filling and only <a href="http://www.veganuary.com/eating-out/indian-cuisine/">coincidentally vegan</a>, it’s a recipe you definitely need in your repertoire.</p><p>The problem is, although aloo gobi has its origins in the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/23/travel/a-culinary-pilgrimage-to-punjab.html?_r=0">Punjab</a>, it’s now a firm favourite across India and Pakistan – and, as Singh observes, “one of the disadvantages of its universal appeal is that there is no such thing as a universal recipe”. Consider this, then, as one very good place to start.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2016/may/12/how-to-cook-the-perfect-aloo-gobi">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>David Wojnarowicz: still fighting prejudice 24 years after his death</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/david-wojnarowicz-close-to-the-knives-a-memoir-of-disintegration-artist-aids-activist</link>
      <description><p>Best known for an image on a U2 album cover, the painter and photographer was was also an Aids activist whose message of defiance from the late 80s reverberates in American politics today</p><p>You might not be familiar with the American artist and activist <a href="https://www.visualaids.org/artists/detail/david-wojnarowicz">David Wojnarowicz</a>’s name, but if you’re of a certain age, you have probably seen at least one image by him. His photograph of buffalo tumbling off a cliff was used as the cover of <a href="http://www.u2.com/discography/index/album/albumId/4039">U2’s <em>One</em></a>, taking his art to a global audience a few months before his death in 1992 of Aids-related complications.</p><p>Wojnarowicz was only 37 when he died, but he left behind an extraordinary body of work, particularly considering the uncongenial circumstances of much of his short life. A refugee from a violent family, a former street kid and teen hustler, he grew up to become one of the stars of the febrile 1980s East Village art scene, alongside <a href="http://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2003/kikismith/">Kiki Smith</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/goldin">Nan Goldin</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/nov/11/keith-haring-review-the-political-side-of-a-pop-art-legend">Keith Haring</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/basquiat">Jean-Michel Basquiat</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/david-wojnarowicz-close-to-the-knives-a-memoir-of-disintegration-artist-aids-activist">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'We are not the Brady Bunch': Empire and the power of family</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/empire-black-family-power-tv-fox</link>
      <description><p>Whether they’re feuding, backstabbing or singing in perfect harmony, the TV family have unshakeable bonds many African Americans can relate to</p><p>Whatever feelings you may have about <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/31/empire-season-two-return-fox">Empire</a> as a television series, one thing that is resolutely clear from episode to episode, is that it stands to represent the power of family – in particular, black family. The bond between the Lyons, whether they are manipulating each other, saying downright evil, abhorrent things to each other or singing in pitch perfect harmony, is utterly unbreakable. And while I admire and envy it, I also don’t entirely understand it. I was adopted as an infant into a white family, and reunited with my white birthmother when I was 11 years old (I didn’t reunite with my black birthfather until I was in my early 20s), after which I spent 20 years trying to straddle two families – neither of which I felt I belonged to or bonded with completely. As with any family, that did not prevent reprehensible behavior toward one another, but I have never known or felt the kind of loyalty that the Lyon family brings us every week.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/31/empire-season-two-return-fox">Fall of Empire: show's big return is a lesson on how not to run a record label</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/empire-black-family-power-tv-fox">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Prince Charles: I use homeopathy in animals to cut antibiotic use</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/prince-charles-use-homeopathy-in-animals-to-cut-antibiotic-use</link>
      <description><p>Homeopathy sceptic Dame Sally Davies among delegates to hear prince say he treats his cows with alternative medicine</p><p>Prince Charles has proposed a solution to the growing crisis of antibiotic over-use in animals and humans, telling an international gathering of scientists and government officials in London that he treats his own cows and sheep with homeopathy.</p><p>In front of the government’s chief medical officer, Dame Sally Davies, who once told a parliamentary committee that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/may/08/jeremy-hunt-homeopathy-studies-chief-medical-officer">homeopathy in humans was “rubbish”</a> and that she was “perpetually surprised that homeopathy is available on the NHS”, the prince explained to delegates from 20 nations and organisations why he had turned to homeopathic remedies for animals.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/12/prince-charles-use-homeopathy-in-animals-to-cut-antibiotic-use">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ori Gersht's best photograph: a bullet hitting a pomegranate at 1,600 frames per second</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/11/ori-gershts-best-photograph-a-bullet-hitting-a-pomegranate-at-1600-frames-per-second</link>
      <description><p>‘I used a pomegranate instead of a quince – since pomegranates explode like grenades’</p><p>This image references a 1602 Baroque still life by Juan Sánchez Cotán titled <a href="http://www.wga.hu/frames-e.html?/html/s/sanchez/cotan/stillife.html" title="">Quince, Cabbage, Melon and Cucumber</a>. It’s a very cerebral painting, because he was trying to create a sense of perfect static balance. It must have taken an awfully long time. My photograph was&nbsp;an act of destruction, taken at an unthinkable speed. I decided to use a&nbsp;pomegranate, instead of a quince, because a pomegranate would explode&nbsp;like a grenade.</p><p>I took it after a long period in Ukraine, photographing the landscapes my grandfather-in-law would have seen when he survived the Holocaust. Soon after, my son was born. I was travelling a&nbsp;lot, and I think I became more introverted. This image came from a need to produce a moment of destruction that&nbsp;would also be a moment&nbsp;of creation.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/11/ori-gershts-best-photograph-a-bullet-hitting-a-pomegranate-at-1600-frames-per-second">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/photography">Photography</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/artanddesign">Art and design</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 16:01:18 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/may/11/ori-gershts-best-photograph-a-bullet-hitting-a-pomegranate-at-1600-frames-per-second</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/4a7b16262528ab4039e7d1a26b1cd64d0ce1acd4/0_368_4000_2400/4000.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=70a2ff4dae3edbf789222ff7363216e1">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Ori Gersht</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/4a7b16262528ab4039e7d1a26b1cd64d0ce1acd4/0_368_4000_2400/4000.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=d7cb6416359f5e76cedcf2799320ad5a">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Ori Gersht</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <dc:creator>Interview by Tom Seymour</dc:creator>
